In the name of Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful

Preface
The second century AH witnessed the emergence of the Sufi movement, when people began turning away from the straight path of being mindful of Allah, fearing Him, remembering Him secretly and openly, and renouncing the world. A group of righteous people were alarmed by people's fierce competition for the world and their racing to indulge in pleasures and amusements. So they withdrew aside, turning to the Truth, Glory be to Him, devoting themselves to worship, reciting the Book of Allah, and standing in prayer at night, performing Tahajjud and Tahlil (saying La ilaha illa Allah) secretly and openly.
A group of these people took it upon themselves to clarify the practical conduct of Sufism. Al-Muhasibi described the behavior of Sufis in a scientific manner in his book "Al-Ri'ayah li-Huquq Allah" (Observance of the Rights of Allah). The ways of Sufism until the sixth century AH were generally close to asceticism (Zuhd), despite some deviations from the right path that mixed with it at times. However, the grave events that befell the Islamic state since the late sixth century AH and early seventh century AH created an opposite reaction. Some turned away from life and its affairs and leaned towards fatalism (Tawakul), and asceticism in their customs became a kind of indifference reaching the point of submissiveness.

The beginning was when the Ayyubids resolved to confront the Shiite current of thought following the collapse of the Fatimid state. The Ayyubids established numerous schools and Hadith houses in Egypt and the Levant, and summoned Sunni scholars and jurists to play their role in those institutions. Many Islamic cities such as Alexandria, Cairo, Qus, Asyut, Jerusalem, Aleppo, Damascus, and Tripoli became vibrant centers for Sunni sciences and thought.
Then came the fierce Crusader invasion to add other burdens, casting its weight on Saladin. He worked to establish the Arab and Islamic identity of the lands that were the target of the new invaders. He established Khanqahs (Sufi hospices), Ribats (hospices/fortresses), Zawiyas (corners), and Tekkes, in addition to mosques, schools, Hadith houses, and hospitals (Bimaristans). Saladin's goal behind this was to revive religious feeling among Muslims and raise the readiness of the Islamic nation to resist the dangers threatening it.
A group of people occupied these places, taking up Dhikr (remembrance) and reading the Quran as their profession. They followed the straight path and were good models for the pious and worshippers. However, these places soon became a refuge and sanctuary for every comfort seeker, finding therein what they sought of food, clothing, and drink without significant effort. This was followed by an increase in the numbers of those joining the ranks of Sufism, especially after the number of Khanqahs, Ribats, Zawiyas, and Tekkes multiplied, and people exaggerated in endowing Waqfs (religious endowments) for them, and Sultans, Princes, and the wealthy competed in offering money and gifts to their frequenters. Thus, the life of the Sufis became easy, and they enjoyed a luxurious and opulent life, which led to the spread of innovations later on.
Consequently, claiming to be Sufi became common for the purpose of livelihood. Many headed to the Khanqahs, wore wool, and shaved their heads, but they did not adopt the morals of

They said: "We seek refuge in Allah from the Fire, and from the Sufi if he knows the door of the house." Another description of their condition was: "Eaters, idle, hashish addicts (Satla), having no work or occupation." Many jurists defined the group of Sufis as "men who display Islam but conceal corrupt belief, wearing skulls on their legs and their turbans' tails from the front" (1).
What increased the rushing of groups of people to join the ranks of Sufism was the occurrence of the devastating Tartar-Mongol invasion of the Islamic world, and the bitterness and disappointment it bequeathed in souls. Also, the hardship of living that characterized that era due to drought and famine, so famines persisted, and infectious diseases like plague and smallpox and other deadly diseases spread.
These people found in the Khanqahs ample living and ease of condition, indeed luxury in food, drink, and clothing. This is because many interests and establishments, such as orchards, shops, bathhouses, and markets, were endowed (Waqf) for the Sufis. The Sa'id al-Su'ada Khanqah in Egypt, established in 569 AH = 1173 AD, had a number of interests endowed to it to spend from their revenue on the poor Sufis, including the Habbaniyah orchard and the Sharab Qaysariyah (market). Each Sufi there was allocated three loaves weighing a third of a Ratl in broth, and sweets were made for its Sufis every month, and soap was distributed to them (2). As for the Sufis of the Rukn al-Din Baybars Khanqah, a kitchen was attached to it, from which meat, food, and three loaves were distributed to the residents every day, in addition to

As for the Sufis of the Siryaqus Khanqah, they had the price of clothing every year and extra allowance in every Ramadan, the two Eids, and seasons, on top of what they had of delicious food and pure bread, in addition to sweets, olive oil, soap, and the price of fruits. This is besides the sugar, various drinks, and types of medicines available in the Khanqah. Bathhouses, kitchens, and burial places were also attached to the Khanqahs, and their floors were spread with carpets, copper utensils, books, lamps, and other precious tools, which only kings and princes acquire.
Anyone who looks at the endowment deeds of Khanqahs, Zawiyas, and Ribats realizes the extent of the economic burden suffered by society due to the narrow base benefiting from the economic interests restricted to Sufis to the exclusion of other segments of society.
As evidence of the extravagant and luxurious life enjoyed by the Sufis, we present two examples of Sama' (Sufi musical gatherings) held in Egypt and the Levant in the year 659 AH = 1261 AD.
"Mawla Qutb al-Din, may Allah have mercy on him, said: One of the Nasiriyyah narrated to me, saying: When we entered the Egyptian lands, it happened that one of the senior Emirs held a Sama', and he came himself to Emir Jamal al-Din and invited him. He promised him to go to him and attend. When it was the time of the last Isha prayer, he went, and we were with him - a group of his Mamluks and retinue - to that Emir's house. When he entered, he found a group of Emirs sitting in the Iwan of the house, and a group of Fuqara (Sufis) in the middle of the house. He stopped and did not enter, and said to the owner of the house: You erred in what you did. The Fuqara should have been seated above and you

He used to hold Sama' gatherings for them, bringing in foods, drinks, good perfumes, and candles that dazzle the mind and exceed the limit. It was estimated that what he spent on a single Sama' was approximately eight thousand Dirhams (2)... etc.

When the Maghrib prayer was performed, he spread a table for the Fuqara (Sufis) containing nearly a hundred Adiliyyah bowls. In each bowl was a whole suckling lamb, and about three hundred bowls in each of which were three chickens, and other types of food. After Isha and completing the prayer, those present began singing and dancing. When they got tired, he spread a table of sweets and Qatayef (pancakes), fresh and fried, made with Egyptian sugar, pistachios, and musk. Then they danced and sang all together. Then, a huge table of rare fruits out of season was spread, including quince, apples, pears, pomegranates, and melons. After that, they returned to dancing and singing. Then he spread a table of various nuts, Iraqi sugarcane, pistachios, hazelnuts, raisins, stuffed cakes, Khushkanan (discs of flour and sweets), rusks, and others. Their drink was made with snow and sugar, willow water (a type of distilled Egyptian willow), and rose water, in addition to censers filled with aloeswood, ambergris, and Indian oud. When it was the time of Suhur (pre-dawn), they entered a bathhouse adjacent to Lajin's house, bathed, and were dressed in new shirts and clothes. After the bath, they returned to the house and were given drinks suitable after a bath, then a table of hot sweets was spread for them, and after that they left.
To estimate the condition of the people at that time, Al-Yunini commented on the occurrence of this Sama', stating that it was held while people were in hardship. A Ghararah of wheat in Damascus cost three hundred Dirhams, a Ratl of meat in Damascus cost seven Dirhams, and a chicken cost three Dirhams. All things were very expensive. So look at what luxury and prosperity the Sufis of that era lived in?

The role of Sufis was not limited to economic sabotage, but extended to influencing political and social events, through the infiltration of the movement among the common people and the elite. Consequently, the state recognized Sufi institutions and brought Sufi sheikhs close, to the extent that Sultans boasted of building Ribats, Khanqahs, and Zawiyas for the Sufi group, believing that the poor Sufis could perform miracles, remove harm from Sultans, and claim unveiling (Mukashafa) and witnessing the Truth (1). Therefore, the poor Sufis were often invited to lift harm from an afflicted person, or to pray for wellness for a sick person (2).
The influence of the Sheikh of Sheikhs of the Sa'id al-Su'ada Khanqah reached such an extent that he succeeded in banishing Ibn Taymiyyah from Egypt to the Levant in the year 707 AH = 1307 AD, where he was imprisoned in Damascus, on the pretext of speaking against the Sheikhs of the Path (Tariqa). The Sheikh of Sa'id al-Su'ada had gathered over five hundred Sufis from the Khanqah and marched with them in a demonstration to the Citadel, and large groups of commoners had joined the demonstration. At the Citadel, they complained to the Sultan about Ibn Taymiyyah, who referred them to the Shafi'i judge, who pushed them away to Taqi al-Din Ali bin al-Zawawi al-Maliki, who in turn issued the ruling we referred to (3). Also in Damascus, Ibn Ramadan the Witness was reprimanded because he spoke against the Fuqara (4), and was beaten until he sought repentance and forgiveness. Indeed, Sufis often spilled wines and Boza because they are forbidden for

Manifestations of Corruption in the Life of Sufis
- Sama' (Listening to Music) and Dancing: Sama' for Sufis are nights held in which they chant and dance. In their definition, Sama' generates a state in the heart called Wajd (ecstasy), and this in turn moves the body members. If the movements are rhythmic, they are clapping and dancing; if unweighted, they are agitations (1). It seems that a kind of whim and overpowering control the Sufi; if he hears singing or a rhythmic beat with a stick, he goes into ecstasy, claps, and perhaps tears his clothes and throws them (2).
A group of scholars denounced such disgraceful behavior and wrote books and poems condemning their conduct. Imam Muwaffaq al-Din, Abdullah bin Ahmad bin Muhammad bin Qudamah al-Maqdisi wrote a treatise condemning what the pretenders of Sufism do of singing, dancing, going into ecstasy, beating the tambourine, listening to flutes, and raising voices objectionably with what they call Dhikr (remembrance) and Tahlil, claiming it is a type of closeness to Allah Almighty.
Many poets satirized them, such as Shaddad bin Ibrahim nicknamed Al-Tahir Al-Jazari, and the Dean Abu Muhammad Abdullah, Ahmad bin Ibrahim Al-Zawawi the scribe, and Zahir al-Din the judge of Salamiyah d. 610 AH = 1213 AD (3), who satirized Makki, the Sheikh of the Fuqara Zawiya in Bawazij, a small town near Salamiyah, saying: [Mutaqarib Meter]
Tell Makki the advice of a sincere advisor ... For the right of advice is to be listened to
When did people hear in their religion ... That singing is a Sunnah to be followed?

It seems that incident took place on the first day of the fast, or the first Sunday of the fast according to Al-Shabushti's narration in Al-Diyarat (1), and that day became a celebration for them where men mix with women.
Ibn al-Jawzi pointed out that the Sufis of his time had closed the door of looking at foreign women upon themselves, due to their distance from associating with them and their refraining from mixing with them, and busied themselves with worship instead of marriage. But companionship of young boys happened to them in the guise of discipleship (Irada) and intent of asceticism (2). Ibn al-Jawzi decides that the bane of Sufis in his time was in accompanying young boys and associating with opposites (3). The calamity did not stop at this limit but went beyond it to legitimize that for the Sufis. Abu al-Fadl, Muhammad bin Tahir, known as Ibn al-Qaysarani al-Shaybani d. 507 AH = 1113 AD wrote a treatise on the permissibility of Sama' and looking at beardless youths (4).

Although the phenomenon of accompanying beardless youths, young boys, and effeminates was clear in the late Abbasid eras, it intensified in the Mamluk era, following the arrival of a sect of Oirat Tatars (2), famous for beauty in the year 695 AH = 1295 AD, and their spread in Egypt and the Levant, and then entering the service of Mamluk Emirs. The Mamluk Emirs competed in acquiring their boys and girls. Those remaining of these Oirats after that joined the army, and dispersed in the kingdoms spreading corruption with them. Groups of Sufis found what they were looking for in them, so they exaggerated in conferring Sufi legitimacy on their heinous act. Al-Sha'rani - one of the major Sufis of the tenth century AH - reported to us the news of the righteous Muhammad bin Iraqi, who would not enable his son Ali to go out to the market, when he was beardless, unless he was veiled for fear for him from evil and temptation (Fitna) (3).
The matter did not stop at beardless youths and young boys but extended to others like beasts and animals. The Sufi Sheikh Ali Wahish (d. 917 AH / 1511 AD) was a frequent assaulter of beasts and female donkeys (4).
This type of Sufism was a mockery of religions, a distance from the path of asceticism and worship, and shamelessness, until the Sufis of the centuries following the sixth

- Consuming Hashish: A number of Sufis persisted in consuming hashish, claiming that it removes dense worries from their hearts, and clears their noble thoughts by its effect. We do not have a reliable text regarding how it entered the Islamic world, as narrations about it have varied. Some narrations attribute it to the Indian Birzatan who carried it with him from India to Persia in the first century AH, and then it was transferred by the Qalandariyyah group who were organized in the ranks of Sufism, and they shaved their heads, eyebrows, and mustaches (2).
Another narration attributes its discovery to Sheikh Haydar d. 618 AH = 1221 AD, who made it a Waqf (endowment) for his comrades from the Sufis of Khorasan, and bequeathed that it be planted on his grave after his death. From there it moved to Baghdad, then the Levant and Egypt. It is worth noting that the Haydariyyah group came to Damascus after the year 655 AH = 1257 AD, wearing conical hats (Taratir) on their heads, their beards cut, and their mustaches uncut. Analysis of the Material of the Treatise We Are Publishing:
The treatise discussed an important economic issue, which is: Is Waqf (endowment) and Will (Wasiyya) for Sufis valid or not? Because a large number of the town's interests, such as shops, bathhouses, markets, orchards, agricultural villages, mills, presses, and others, were endowed to the Sufis of a Khanqah or recommended to spend their revenue on a specific Sufi group. Consequently, only a handful of society benefits from these interests, enjoying their goods and gifts. They even influenced the course of political and social events in the nation, becoming influential and close to the rulers. In fact, the rulers themselves began to fear them, so they fawned over them by exaggerating in honoring them and lavishing money on them.
These Sufis constituted a heavy burden on the economy of society. The locals and farmers were burdened by providing for their needs, hoping to please them and gain their prayers. Goals were reversed, and Sufis drowned in corruption and corruption-spreading, directing social life as they wished. Their aura grew, and their influence exacerbated. So a group of scholars undertook the task of alerting society to the state of deterioration the Sufi movement had reached, by awakening feelings for the principles of true Sufism. This group of scholars re-examined Sufism and the reality of the Sufi in terms of principles and goals. The intent of that was to raise the issue among people, so they could compare the condition of Sufis in their time with what they ought to be.

This chapter is the core of the treatise and the main purpose for its composition. This chapter enters into the theories of obligation and commitment in civil law jurisprudence, in the merits of "Custom" (Urf). The legal material he presents is that custom is arbiter and decisive in dispute if it is disciplined and undisputed in a specific country. If custom is disturbed in that country, clarification becomes obligatory then, meaning the ruling is linked to causes. He sent Muhammad from the noblest tribes and most honorable elements, and made him foremost in virtue even if his existence was in the later time. And He singled him out with companions who are like shining stars, the elite of creation, and upholders of the truth, so pinkies are counted upon them [in enumerating virtues]. They are the people of purity, masters of loyalty, seniors of masters, and masters of seniors. So may Allah bless him and his family and companions, a prayer by which abundant, ample reward is attained, and clothes with the best garments and finest prides.
TO PROCEED: A discussion has occurred regarding the name of Sufism (Tasawwuf), the reality of the Sufi, and who deserves the revenue of what is endowed (Waqf) or bequeathed (Wasiyya) to the Sufis. So these are three requirements.
Requirement One:
Tasawwuf (Sufism): It is an expression for intending the path of a specific group called Sufiyyah, by which one characterizes oneself. It was said about it: It is from the form 'Tafa'ul', when one enters into the action like your saying: 'Taqammasa' (he put on a shirt), if he wore the shirt.

Requirement Two: On the reality of the Sufi

One of them: On Attribution.
The second: On explaining whom the attribution truly applies to.
First Standing: Attribution.

Wearing wool and cotton is predominant in this state. Wool is more predominant due to the generality of its existence, and its roughness is more than the roughness of cotton. In the Sahih Hadith from Abu Burda, he said: Aisha brought out for us a thick cloak and a thick Izar (lower garment), and said: The [soul of] the Messenger of Allah was taken in these two (2). Al-Tirmidhi narrated from the Hadith of Abdullah bin Masoud from the Prophet who said: "Upon Moses the day his Lord spoke to him was a cloak of wool, a Jubba of wool, a Kumma (cap) of wool, and trousers of wool (3). The Second Station: Regarding who this attribution applies to
It applies in two considerations:
First, Custom (Urf), in the language of the early people of the Path (Ahl al-Tariqah).
Second, in the specific Custom in our time and what is close to it.
As for the early ones, their expressions varied regarding that, but the meaning is one or close. Al-Nuri was asked about the Sufi, he said: He who hears the Sama' (spiritual listening) and prefers leaving causes (means of livelihood). Ibn al-Jalla' (1) was asked about him, he said: We do not know him within the condition of knowledge, but he is a Faqir (poor one) stripped of causes, and he was with Allah without a place" (2).

The possessor of Karamat (miracles), Abd al-Malik al-Attar said: He is the one who sought the Halal, accompanied the Men (of God), and restrained his tongue from speech, so his state informs about him.

The Hafiz, Abu al-Faraj Abd al-Rahman bin al-Jawzi the Jurist (2) said: He is the one who renounced desires, abandoned lusts, made up for what passed of his life, revived what died of it, protected his mind from dispersion, and feared his Lord until death.

We have clarified that the name 'Sufism' originated after the Prophet, the Companions, the Tabi'in, and the followers of the Tabi'in. The principle in legal rulings is that they are attached to a regulated matter. It only departs from this where the Sharia requires an action from us and we find it does not link to a regulated matter, so we attach the ruling to a matter that indicates that well for the sake of the Lawgiver's request. Endowment for Sufis or bequest to them did not appear in the Sharia. Perhaps it occurred after the extinction of the blessed eras and the departure of the Imams of Ijtihad, for I have not come across it for anyone before four hundred (AH).
Then, what we link it to of appearance does not remove dispute and difference due to its instability. Al-Ghazali said in Al-Ihya (1): "Sufism is an internal matter, not visible, so the ruling cannot be linked to it, but rather to apparent matters relied upon by people of custom in applying the name Sufi. This which Al-Ghazali mentioned does not suit his verification, because the book Al-Ihya is not designed for verification according to the method of Fiqh, and most or much of it is built on Sufi speech, and his classification in Fiqh was after that. He referred in his Fiqh books to things he mentioned in Al-Ihya. As for craft and occupation with books, it prevents entitlement. So the farmer, the worker, the merchant, the jeweler (1) in his shop or house, and the hireling who serves for his wage, all of these do not deserve from the endowment for the Sufis and are not compensated by dress and mixing.
As for copying (Warraqah) and tailoring and what is close to them of what is appropriate for Sufis to engage in, if he engages in them not in a shop nor by way of earning and craft, that does not prevent entitlement and is compensated by cohabitation along with being characterized by the rest of the attributes. As for preaching and teaching, it does not contradict the name of Sufism if the rest of the descriptions of dress, cohabitation, and poverty are present, since Sufi Reciter, Preacher, Scholar, Teacher (2) does not contradict, all of this does not contradict. What contradicts is to say Farmer or Merchant or Worker.
As for Poverty, if it is removed by excessive wealth by which the man is attributed to apparent riches, entitlement is prevented even if he has wealth, but his income does not cover his expenditure, or he has wealth falling short of the obligation of Zakat. If he claims that this is a consistent custom in times and places, there is no evidence for it, and what he said is not accepted. And if he claims a custom specific to a time or place, it is a specific custom, and specific custom has no consideration according to the people of Fatwa.
Do you not see that Musaqat (sharecropping) according to our companions is carried upon custom, and they made the oxen upon the owner considering the general custom in their induction. Then the custom of our entire lands is that it is upon the worker, and he did not pay attention to this specific one, rather they stated that if it was stipulated upon the worker the contract is void, and likes of that are many in various chapters.
Then, custom if found is only considered where it agrees with what evidences indicated its consideration, and the opponent from Sharia or language is negated from it, and it is general among that group. And what he mentioned is originated after four hundred, and after the passing of the people of realities from this Sufi group, and the masters of observed customs.
